reviewText: Dogfight 1942 is an arcade WW2 airplane shooter where you pilot various planes on all fronts, jumping from hotspot to hotspot, taking roles of different pilots. You're be jumping from Pearl Harbor to Battle of Britain, from infiltrating occupied France in a captured Bf-110 to torpedo bombing the Japanese flatops at Midway, and many more. The controls must be played with an Xbox360 controller or similar twin-analog controllers (or mouse/keyboard), as this uses mainly the RC plane control method. The AI handles stuff like landing gear and throttle, you just concentrate on turn and burn. Landing is often done for a little extra challenge, and occasionally you need to go after an enemy ace. On easy the planes are responsive and the plane even regenerates" if you don't get hit for a while. There's even kill cams where the victim of your gun mastery breaks apart in a shower of flames. There are variety of activities
hoursPlayed: and if you are desperate you can even call in your wingmen to assist. Graphics are quite good. This is not a sim
voteText: nor does it pretend to be

reviewText: A rather simplistic approach on World War 2 aerial combat, letting you enjoy the fantasy of participating in some of the greatest battles of the war without reading 800 pages of manuals and learning about aerodynamics. It is mindless and somewhat dull if played for too long in a single session, but in short bursts manages to pull off being a fun little arcade-game that is all about nicely modeled aircraft blowing up in spectacular kill-cam-cutscenes and some beautiful looking combat areas (particularly when you rise above the clouds towards the sun).\n\nThere is no clutter in this, get in there, blow stuff up, return home - rinse and repeat. If you are expecting more, you need to look elsewhere - especially realism has been dropped to provide a more fun, arcade-ish experience - which I feel is the way this needs to be played as it reminds me of earlier Ace Combat-titles or Crimson Skies (while not being as good as both of these series). If you just want to blow some fascists out of the sky, this is the way to go - just don't expect a simulation like IL-2 Sturmovik and you will be fine.
voteText: 27 of 32 people (84%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Little WW2 arcade sim... it runs quite smoothly, there's some mission variety to keep things from getting boring and it controls OK with a gamepad.
I played at the default difficulty level + Simulation mode; it is a bit on the easy side, but not without some mild challenge here and there, missions do not drag too long, and there is at least one checkpoint, usually more, in between, so you'll never have to repeat too much if you fail.

Completed the main campaign in about 3.5 hours, and i guess there is a couple more hours to play to complete both DLC.... all in all, not a bad title if you like this sort of gameplay and can get it cheap.
voteText: 18 of 20 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Dogfight 1942 is exactly what it sounds like, an Aerial combat game taking place after the events of Pearl Harbor during The Second World War. Instead of being a Flight Combat Simulator, Dogfight 1942 is more of a Flight Combat Arcade-type game. Playing with a traditional Keyboard and Mouse, I found the flying to be slightly unrealistic and to smooth to classify it as a simulator; However, it still has appeal as a fun aerial combat game. Similar to the Ace Combat series, You attack a varying range of adversaries both Aerial and ground-based, using a variety of different period aircraft you unlock through campaigning. The game can be played in Campaign mode, Through Single-player as well as Coop play with online friends. Graphically, I think it looks decent for the type of game it is. The scoring system, as well as earning 5 stars on each mission are what really give it an arcade feel. For a World War 2 type combat game, you could do worse. For an Aerial combat game, I've played much worse. Dogfight 1942 has some appeal, especially if you have friends whom you want to thrash with your own high score.

reviewText:
**edit below**
From a purely arcade standpoint, this is one heck of a lot of fun. Only 3 missions in so far, but this is the best flying fun I've had since the Aces series by Dynamix (Sierra). Take-off and landing are quite simplified in arcade mode, which is fine by me. I wanted an up-close dogfighting game with nice graphics for this decade and that's what I have got. All the more modern war-flight sims focus so much more on reading the radar screens and locking on targets to take down the enemy. This is up-close, personal, get 'em in your cross-hairs and take 'em down fun.
So far, 4 out of 5 stars

Finished Act 1, parts of Act 2 and some QuickPlay. rating goes higher - 4.5 outta 5 stars
voteText: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
★★★★★★★☆☆☆

A surprisingly fun little arcadey dog fighting game. As of writing this the price is £7 and while I'm not sure I'd pay that, I certainly would pay pretty much any sale price.

The game can be a little confusing at some points with regards to how to execute certain parts of a mission, but other than that the game runs really well and is a genuinely fun experience in a genre which is currently very sparse.

My only minor gripe with it is that it's rather short and the controls feel a bit floaty, but other than that it's an enjoyable game.
voteText: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Well it's no simulator. But if you don't want to spend a lot of time reading a hefty manual you're in for a treat. The missions offer a great diversity of tasks and you've the chance to fly a lot of different planes. The aircraft models and the overall graphics are decent enough and if you want to take some amazing screenshots wait for the killcam. The missions are short enough to complete in 15 to 20 minutes max - so if you're no hardcore simulation gamer just hop in your plane and have some casual fun.\nI strongly recommend to buy the DLC as you get a lot more content.\nThe game is well optimized and runs smoothly on my system - (see my profile) - and it's worth the asking price although if you're patient you can pick it up on sale quite often.

reviewText:
I hate to say this, but Dogfight 1942 is a terrible game. I'm sure there are worse action flight combat (it's nothing even remotely close to a simulator, but it was never intended to be either) games out there, but saying something isn't the absolute worst thing you've ever played" isn't exactly a ringing endorsement.

Let's break this down into categories:

GRAPHICS: I know this game isn't brand new
date: but it's only three years old
recommended: having been released in 2012. For a game that's still that recent
hoursPlayed: the graphics resemble something from a PS2 title more than anything else. I mean it has low quality polygons
voteText: bad textures
votesHelpful: etc. If this game had been released in 2005
votesTotal: I'd have said it looked great
votesFunny: but as a game released in 2012? No
commentsCount: it's definitely not a good looking game.\n\nAUDIO: The sound effects aren't terrible and the music is okay. The voice acting is fine
column17: although it's a bit overdone.\n\nThe one thing that really annoys me about the audio
column19: is that the game refuses to acknowledge the volume controls on my keyboard
column20: so in order to change the volume quickly I have to ALT + TAB out. That's simply unacceptable.\n\nCONTROLS: You can use a mouse and keyboard setup or a gamepad. I've been using an XBox 360 gamepad
column21: and the controls feel very responsive. No complaints here.\n\nSAVE GAME METHOD: Checkpoints during the mission and after the mission
column22: The checkpoints during the mission are also only good while you're playing
column23: so if you need to quit
column24: be prepared to replay everything over (as of that mission
column25: not the entire game). If you complete the mission
column26: then it also saves and when you continue it'll go onto the next mission.\n\nAlthough I consider checkpoints to be a cheap and lazy way of handling saves
column27: I didn't expect much else from a console port. Overall
column28: this didn't have a negative effect on the game
column29: unless I had to quit for some reason.\n\nGAMEPLAY: This is the big one
column31: it's also where Dogfight 1942 does the worst. As a simple mindless action game it's decent
column32: but the problem is that it's very unclear on the objectives and rarely gives you enough time to complete them.\n\nFor instance
column33: there's a mission where you need to avoid detection
column34: and there's a bar showing you how detectable you are to enemy ships. That seems good and all
column35: but the bar raises and lowers in a seemingly arbitrary way. The way you complete this is by moving all over the place and hoping the game skips to the next cutscene (thereby creating a checkpoint) before you're noticed.\n\nIn another mission
column36: you need to sink a bunch of enemy ships that're attacking your fleet. Halfway through
column37: you have to divert to shoot down enemy bombers who're attacking your airfield. Then you need to fly back to your side's ships and continue trying to destroy the enemy's ships. The problem is they don't give you nearly enough time to complete this
column38: so even if you save your airfield
column39: you'll still fail the mission because you didn't sink all the Japanese ships.\n\nWorse yet
column40: if you don't immediately know what they want and how they want you to do it
column41: they'll start chastising you. I'm not exaggerating either. In one mission they began berating me for not finding a hidden airfield after I'd been flying for two seconds. I actually counted
column43: it was two seconds!\n\nSo what's good about the game? Basically
column44: the single missions section (where you take to the sky and shoot down however many planes listed) and co-op gameplay. You can play local co-op in the campaign and single missions
column45: so that's fun. Perhaps the game assumes you'll be playing co-op and that's why the game doesn't give much time to complete anything.\n\nVERDICT: I'm going to say
column47: I don't think it's worth buying." However
column48: if you're absolutely desperate for a WWII-era flight action combat game
column49: or you have someone you can play local co-op with
column50: I'd suggest this title ONLY if you can get it on a substantial sale of 75% off or more. Otherwise
column51: stay away from it as it'll only cause a ton of frustration."

reviewText: Piloting a wide range of aircraft, players engage in aerial dogfights and dangerous fighter missions across the major theaters of war during WWII. Featuring realistic aircraft, DOGFIGHT 1942 introduces cutting-edge flight dynamics with unprecedented arcade accessibility. Fly over 40 historically accurate planes, ranging from the fabled P-38 Lightning and Britain's Spitfire, to the feared Messerschmitt 109 and Japanese Kate.

reviewText: Poor controls and control execution make for an annoying arcade version of WW2 aerial combat. While on the surface this game appears to be fun, after a few missions the quirks overwhelm much of the good to be had - Focusing on a target aircraft, while helpful for individual kills makes it almost impossible to spray an entire formation of enemy bombers. The missions that involve bombing targets are even worse, since there is little feedback given and plane control gets rather loopy. This last may have been an attempt to increase how realistic the game may seem, but fails in this regard since it makes the lack of other feedback mechanisms (say a click" when a bomb is release") more noticeable.\n\nAdditionally
hoursPlayed: the HUD in game leave a lot to be desired. Why isn't there a compass
voteText: altimeter or anything to indicate horizon? The lack of these contribute to the light
helpfulPercent: arcade feel but not in a good way.\n\nI don't have any comments on the missions themselves - I know how the "story" turns out and was more interested in shooting planes out of the sky than saving the world."

reviewText:
Recommended, but only if
1) You can get it cheap, because it's short. (took me 4 hours to finish, including DLC's, on normal difficulty)
2) You're not looking for a realistic sim. This is pure arcade action. You single handedly drop squadrons of aircraft and sink entire fleets.
3) You don't mind repetition. You only have four types of weapons, of which three are basically against ground targets. Missions basically consist of shooting aircraft, shooting ground targets and sinking ships. Couple of mid-mission landings excluded.

Nothing really wrong with it, but doesn't excel at anything either. Decent fun for an evening or two.

reviewText:
A nice arcade game of a flying simulator set during WW2.  The game is definitely on the easier (and arcade) side of things with unlimited bombs, missiles, guns...your plane also has boost  and can heal itself...but it is all entertaining.

The game has very nice graphics and uses a nice variety of air-to-air combat and air-to-ground combat (with missiles and bombs) so it never felt like doing the same thing over and over.  The game itself is a short game with the DLCs particularly short, and more of the same (which is good if you like the base game), just with new voice accents.

Main Campaign ~2.8 hrs
DLC - Russia Under Siege:  0.9 hrs
DLC - Sands of Africa:  0.7 hrs

Overall, a short and well done flying arcade game.  8 out of 10.

reviewText:
All good things come in threes - Three modes, for three kinds of aerial simulation players - Casual, Arcade and Simulation (from easiest to hardest), three difficulty levels, three types of weapons - guns, rockets and bombs/torpedoes.
All this, topped with a realistic WWII setting, covering both the European theatre with RAF vs. Luftwaffe skirmishes, and the wars of the Imperial Japanese Navy and the US Navy, fought by brave pilots just as much as by the ship's crews.
The planes come in a lot of variety and with customization options for camouflage, nose art, side art and wing art.
I would add that this is one of the historically accurate games set in WWII. It's one of the very few games that I've seen to feature the use of V-1 flying rockets by the Luftwaffe, in one desperate attempt to utterly wreck London.
Aerial combat in World War II was the beginning of a new era of aerial warfare, with the development and use of jetfighters in the European theater. The Gloster Meteor of the RAF, and countering it, introduced in the game soon afterwards - the Luftwaffe's Me-262. This is actually depicted in the game in a very cinematic manner and (minor spoiler) some lines hint to this feeling of change. On encountering the old BF-109s, the RAF squadron remarks that the Jerries are still flying those old Messers, hoping to be the dominant air power with the superior Meteors, but as if waiting for the words to be uttered enters a German jetfighter - the Me-262.
There's historical battles, air to air, air to land, air to sea combat; there's local co-op and multiplayer; there's survival mode (somewhat like the Survival mode of Modern Warfare 3 or the Firefight mode of Halo series); there's your favourite airplanes from the WWII era - do you see a reason *not* to call this simply one of the best games of the genre?

reviewText:
This game is basically an arcade game - unrealistic physics and gameplay.

I shot down more planes in the first three missions than most WWII pilots did in their entire careers - and that's not a brag - it's just insanely simple to score. No cockpit view, no stick support (360 gamepads are supported), and linear gameplay.

And it's a mediocre game experience - bombers show up and bomb things before your get a chance to fight them, so their is no deviation from the script - the story is a straight line. And it's not even a good story - one minuite you're the Pacific theater, the next you're in Europe - so, no continuity.

It's polished - lots of voice acting, and the graphics are okay, but it is just lacking. There are much better arcade style flight games than this. This one is just unremarkable.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Dogfight 1942... What a game!! Before playing this I checked out some of the reviews and there were some negative comments, mostly positive, but the negatives were mainly concerning the controls, lack of storyline, and unrealsim (one guy commented on how the game sucked due to the fact your bombs and torpedos reload whilst in mid air). So these are my opinions! This is game is FAR from a simulator, so if you're looking for a WW2 based flying simulator, this isn't your game! It's a fun, quick paced flight game based around WW2, from all different angles, Japan vs USA, UK vs Germany, and if you have the DLC, making the game a couple of hours longer, you can also play Russia vs Germany, and a mix of countries fighting in the Western Desert Campaign. The plane models are well made and look good, and the Ace camouflages are a good unlock feature and look amazing, and the graphics look and work perfectly fine, I even got some pretty tasty screenshots! The people who said this game is too easy" must have played on the lowest difficulty
date: because the skill level between medium and hard levels are such a massive difference. If you like a challenge
recommended: then Hard is the difficulty for you
hoursPlayed: and the mission medals can sometimes be challenging to do aswell. The controls are easy on casual mode
voteText: but extremely difficult on the other 2 modes
helpfulPercent: and to get some medal unlocks and achievements
votesHelpful: you NEED to use simulation mode. Really good game
column16: considering I got this from a bundle site
column17: which I worked out that the game cost me 0.36p. (I got 8 games for £2.88p) 8/10"
